content.body:
> <@rbuckton:matrix.org> The fact we advanced Iterator helpers, which also depends on ad hoc arrows, weakens that argument, IMO.

But iterator helpers work on the receiver. So there is only one closure.

`i.filter(f)` vs `filter(f)(i)`
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @rbuckton:matrix.org
The fact we advanced Iterator helpers, which also depends on ad hoc arrows, weakens that argument, IMO.

But iterator helpers work on the receiver. So there is only one closure.

i.filter(f) vs filter(f)(i)

content.body: Engines aren't saying we can't have any APIs that take a callback
If PFAs are inlined in the presence of a `|>`, then the only other place they would have utility are places where you're already using `=>`.
content.formatted_body: If PFAs are inlined in the presence of a |>, then the only other place they would have utility are places where you're already using =>.

content.body: In which case, `?` vs `=>` doesn't really change the math.
content.formatted_body: In which case, ? vs => doesn't really change the math.

content.body: If I am doing `[1, 2, 3].map(x => add(x, 1))` today, then `[1, 2, 3].map(add(?, 1))` saves a few characters but is functionally similar.
content.formatted_body: If I am doing [1, 2, 3].map(x => add(x, 1)) today, then [1, 2, 3].map(add(?, 1)) saves a few characters but is functionally similar.
